elements.content: Four metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) based on indium and a tetracarboxylate ligand have been synthesized through regulation of the reaction solvent conditions. The resultant compounds exhibited not only rich structural topologies (pts, soc, and unique topologies) but also interesting charge reversal framework features. By regulating the solvent, different building units (indium monomer, trimer) have been generated in situ, and they are connected with the ligand to form ionic frameworks 1–4, respectively. Among the synthesized four ionic frameworks, compounds 3 and 4 maintained keep their crystallinity upon heating temperature up to 300 °C and full removal of solvent guest molecules. Particularly, they also exhibit the charge reversal framework features (3 adopts an overall cationic framework, whereas 4 has an anionic framework). Both compounds 3 and 4 exhibit a notable significant uptake capacity for CO2 and H2; besides that, compounds 3 and 4 also offer excellent selective adsorption of CO2 over N2 and CH4.

elements.content: Four metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) based on indium and a tetracarboxylate ligand have been synthesized through regulation of the solvent conditions, and the resultant compounds are anionic or cationic frameworks with pts, soc, and unprecedented topologies and exhibit high H2 and CO2 uptake capacity.

elements.content: Hydrogen storage and carbon dioxide capture have attracted considerable attention in recent years, since hydrogen is regarded as one of the most promising candidates for the replacement of current carbon-based energy source. Carbon dioxide is one of the main compounds of greenhouse gases; exploring highly efficient adsorbents for carbon capture has been the key. Various porous materials, such as activated carbon, microporous organic polymers, and zeolites, have been extensively studied as adsorbents for these two gases; the common shortages of these traditional materials are either low capacities or difficult regeneration processes. Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as an emerging class of porous materials, have been known for their intriguing structural diversities of architecture and promising potential applications in large areas, especially in gas sorption and separation. In order to develop MOFs for H2 and CO2 sorption, at first the focus was to design and synthesize elongated ligands and their reticulation into frameworks with large surface area. However, some research results show that large surface area is not necessarily advantageous for storing gas molecules in any conditions. Namely, the adsorption properties of H2 and CO2 in MOFs varied with the adsorbate pressure. Generally, at high pressures gas capacities depend on surface areas and pore volumes of the MOFs, whereas, at low pressure, the capacities mainly depend on the heats of adsorption for gas molecules adsorbed in MOFs; therefore, increasing the interaction strength between gas molecules and MOFs can promote the adsorption properties of MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Hydrogen storage and carbon dioxide capture have attracted considerable attention in recent years, since hydrogen is regarded as one of the most promising candidates for the replacement of current carbon-based energy source. Carbon dioxide is one of the main compounds of greenhouse gases; exploring highly efficient adsorbents for carbon capture has been the key. Various porous materials, such as activated carbon, microporous organic polymers, and zeolites, have been extensively studied as adsorbents for these two gases; the common shortages of these traditional materials are either low capacities or difficult regeneration processes. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as an emerging class of porous materials, have been known for their intriguing structural diversities of architecture and promising potential applications in large areas, especially in gas sorption and separation. In order to develop MOFs for H2 and CO2 sorption, at first the focus was to design and synthesize elongated ligands and their reticulation into frameworks with large surface area. However, some research results show that large surface area is not necessarily advantageous for storing gas molecules in any conditions. Namely, the adsorption properties of H2 and CO2 in MOFs varied with the adsorbate pressure. Generally, at high pressures gas capacities depend on surface areas and pore volumes of the MOFs, whereas, at low pressure, the capacities mainly depend on the heats of adsorption for gas molecules adsorbed in MOFs; therefore, increasing the interaction strength between gas molecules and MOFs can promote the adsorption properties of MOFs.

elements.content: As far as we know, there have been several strategies about enhancing interactions between gas molecules and MOFs; among these, the introduction of active sites on a MOF structure has proven to be valuable, since, at low pressure, both H2 and CO2 preferentially bind on the active sites that have large affinity. In addition, low-pressure gas adsorption can be also affected by catenation and interpenetration of the framework. Recently, the charge-induced force in MOFs has been found to have some influence for gas molecules and frameworks. However, the reported studies are mainly on anionic frameworks or on introduced cations into MOFs by postsynthetic. Little research has been done on directly designing and synthesizing MOFs with charge reversal frameworks by using the same metal source and ligands, which should contribute to the MOF structural features and mainly depends on the self-assembly of metal ions and organic ligands. Fortunately, solvent can also affect the conformation of frameworks.
elements.clean_text: As far as we know, there have been several strategies about enhancing interactions between gas molecules and MOFs; among these, the introduction of active sites on a MOF structure has proven to be valuable, since, at low pressure, both H2 and CO2 preferentially bind on the active sites that have large affinity. In addition, low-pressure gas adsorption can be also affected by catenation and interpenetration of the framework. Recently, the charge-induced force in MOFs has been found to have some influence for gas molecules and frameworks. However, the reported studies are mainly on anionic frameworks or on introduced  cations into MOFs by postsynthetic. Little research has been done on directly designing and synthesizing MOFs with charge reversal frameworks by using the same metal source and ligands, which should contribute to the MOF structural features and mainly depends on the self-assembly of metal ions and organic ligands. Fortunately, solvent can also affect the conformation of frameworks.

elements.content: In fact, the solvent plays an important role in the MOF synthesis; it can not only dissolve the reactants and promote the reaction smoothly but also act as template for directing frameworks assembly. Besides that, the solvent has a large amount of species with different molecular polarities, which make it customary to screen a large number of solvents or solvent mixtures to find the suitable conditions for reactions. Since a MOF is one kind of well-known crystalline material, the solvent can not only greatly influence the mechanism of crystal growth but also be incorporated into the crystalline lattice. If a solvent is filling the pores and/or coordinated to the metal centers within the framework, the sorption properties would be also greatly affected not only by the structure of the MOF but also by the chemical environment of the pore surface. Here, four indium–organic frameworks have been successfully obtained by simply changing the solvent under similar synthetic conditions. By regulating the solvent, different building units (indium monomer, trimer) have been generated in situ, and they are connected with the ligand to form ionic frameworks with pts, soc, and unprecedented topologies

elements.content: The ligand H4EBDC was prepared according to the literature. All the other reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Rigaku D/max-2550 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The infrared (IR) spectra were recorded within the 4000–400 cm–1 region on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellets. The peak intensities are described in each spectra as very strong (vs), strong (s), medium (m), weak (w), and broad (br). The elemental analyses were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 element analyzer. The thermal gravimetric analyses (TG) were performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C thermogravimetric analyzer used in air with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. Low-pressure gas sorption measurements were performed on a fully automated micropore gas analyzer Autosorb-1C (Quantachrome Instruments) at a relative pressure up to 1 atm. The cryogenic temperatures were controlled using liquid nitrogen and liquid argon baths at temperatures of 77 and 87 K, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The ligand H4EBDC was prepared according to the literature. All the other reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Rigaku D/max-2550 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The infrared (IR) spectra were recorded within the 4000-400 cm-1 region on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellets. The peak intensities are described in each spectra as very strong (vs), strong (s), medium (m), weak (w), and broad (br). The elemental analyses were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 element analyzer. The thermal gravimetric analyses (TG) were performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C thermogravimetric analyzer used in air with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Low-pressure gas sorption measurements were performed on a fully automated micropore gas analyzer Autosorb-1C (Quantachrome Instruments) at a relative pressure up to 1 atm. The cryogenic temperatures were controlled using liquid nitrogen and liquid argon baths at temperatures of 77 and 87 K, respectively.

elements.content: 5,5′-(1,2-Ethynediyl)­bis­(1,3-benzene­dicarbox­ylic acid) (H4EBDC) (10.0 mg, 0.0285 mmol), In­(NO3)3·​5H2O (40.0 mg, 0.102 mmol), DMF (1.0 mL), DMSO (1.0 mL), and HNO3 (0.10 mL, 2.7 M in DMF) were added to a vial, and the solution was heated to 85 °C for 36 h. Colorless polyhedral crystals were collected and air-dried (17.6 mg, 74% yield based on H4EBDC). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 1, C30H42­N3S2O13In: C 43.33, H 5.09, N 5.05, S 7.71; found: C 42.83, H 4.78, N 4.72, S 7.54.

elements.content: Suitable single-crystals of 1–4 were selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. The intensity data were collected on a Bruker Smart CCD diffractometer for 1–3 and a Bruker SMART Apex 2 diffractometer for 4 by using graphite-monochromated Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data processing was accomplished with the SAINT processing program, and the structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were subjected to anisotropic refinement by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 by using the SHELXTL program. The solvent molecules in compounds 1, 2, and 4 are highly disordered, and attempts to locate and refine the solvent peaks were not reasonable. The SQUEEZE subroutine of the PLATON software suit was used to remove the scattering from the highly disordered guest molecules. The resulting new files were used to further refine the structures.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determinations

Suitable single-crystals of 1-4 were selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. The intensity data were collected on a Bruker Smart CCD diffractometer for 1-3 and a Bruker SMART Apex 2 diffractometer for 4 by using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data processing was accomplished with the SAINT processing program, and the structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were subjected to anisotropic refinement by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 by using the SHELXTL program. The solvent molecules in compounds 1, 2, and 4 are highly disordered, and attempts to locate and refine the solvent peaks were not reasonable. The SQUEEZE subroutine of the PLATON software suit was used to remove the scattering from the highly disordered guest molecules. The resulting new files were used to further refine the structures.

elements.content: The guest molecular formulas of 1–4 are ascertained from elemental analysis, thermogravimetric analysis, and IR spectroscopy, and the formulas are suggested to be [(CH3)2­NH2]­[In­(EBDC)]·​2DMF·​2DMSO·​H2O for 1, [(CH3)2­NH2]­[In­(EBDC)]·​2DMF for 2, [In3O­(EBDC)1.5­(H2O)3]­[NO3]·​2DMF·​2­(CH3CN)·​0.75­(H2O) for 3, and [(CH3)2NH2]­[In3O­(EBDC)1.5­(H2O)3]2­[In­(EBDC)]3·​8DMF·​13­(CH3CN)·​10­(H2O) for 4. Additional details are presented in .

Additional details are presented in .

Here, a solvent-controlled synthesis of crystalline MOFs has been described (); indium and a tetracarboxylate ligand have been chosen as the metal node and linker, respectively. By regulation of the solvent conditions, four MOFs with different structures have been constructed, and the resultant compounds are anionic or cationic frameworks, exhibiting pts, soc, and unprecedented topologies. The structures of the frameworks have been characterized in detail, together with their gas sorption and separation properties.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Here, a solvent-controlled synthesis of crystalline MOFs has been described (); indium and a tetracarboxylate ligand have been chosen as the metal node and linker, respectively. By regulation of the solvent conditions, four MOFs with different structures have been constructed, and the resultant compounds are anionic or cationic frameworks, exhibiting pts, soc, and unprecedented topologies. The structures of the frameworks have been characterized in detail, together with their gas sorption and separation properties.

elements.clean_text: 1  Four Indium-Organic Frameworks Have Been Synthesized by Changing the Solvent under Similar Synthetic Conditions

elements.content: As shown in , reaction between 5,5′-(1,2-ethynediyl)­bis­(1,3-benzene­dicarbox­ylic acid) (H4EBDC) and In­(NO3)3·​5H2O in a, N,N-dimethyl­formamide (DMF)/​dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) solution in the presence of HNO3 yields a homogeneous microcrystalline material, characterized and formulated by elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) studies as [(CH3)2­NH2]­[In­(EBDC)]·​2DMF·​2DMSO·H2O (compound 1). In the crystal structure of 1, each In3+ center is eight-coordinated to oxygen atoms of four carboxylate groups from four EBDC4– ligands. Each ligand binds to four separate In3+ centers. Accordingly, the inorganic ([In­(O2C)4]−) and organic (EBDC4–) MBBs (molecular building block) can be rationalized as building units having tetrahedral and square-planar geometry, respectively (a). The anionic framework in 1 has pts topology and contains two types of intersecting channels along the c and b axes, with an approximate diameter of 6.655 × 5.567 Å and 5.567 × 5.567 Å (point-to-point and including van der Waals radii, b,c). Since both the inorganic ([In­(O2C)4]−) and organic (EBDC4–) MBBs can be simplified into 4-connected node, the resulting structure of 1 is a (4,4)-connected pts network (d) with a [42.84] tile (e). It is worth noting that the overall framework charge is balanced by [(CH3)2­NH2]+ counterions, which resulted from the decomposition of the DMF solvent.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 1 

As shown in , reaction between 5,5'-(1,2-ethynediyl)bis(1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid) (H4EBDC) and In(NO3)3⋅5H2O in a, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF)/dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) solution in the presence of HNO3 yields a homogeneous microcrystalline material, characterized and formulated by elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) studies as [(CH3)2NH2][In(EBDC)]⋅2DMF⋅2DMSO⋅H2O (compound 1). In the crystal structure of 1, each In3+ center is eight-coordinated to oxygen atoms of four carboxylate groups from four EBDC4- ligands. Each ligand binds to four separate In3+ centers. Accordingly, the inorganic ([In(O2C)4]-) and organic (EBDC4-) MBBs (molecular building block) can be rationalized as building units having tetrahedral and square-planar geometry, respectively (a). The anionic framework in 1 has pts topology and contains two types of intersecting channels along the c and b axes, with an approximate diameter of 6.655 × 5.567 Å and 5.567 × 5.567 Å (point-to-point and including van der Waals radii, b,c). Since both the inorganic ([In(O2C)4]-) and organic (EBDC4-) MBBs can be simplified into 4-connected node, the resulting structure of 1 is a (4,4)-connected pts network (d) with a [42.84] tile (e). It is worth noting that the overall framework charge is balanced by [(CH3)2NH2]+ counterions, which resulted from the decomposition of the DMF solvent.

elements.content: A description of the structure of 1: (a) Each In3+ center is eight-coordinated to oxygen atoms of four carboxylate groups from four EBDC4– ligands, and each ligand binds to four separate In3+ centers. The inorganic ([In­(O2C)4]−) node and organic (EBDC4–) node are rationalized as having tetrahedral and square-planar geometry, respectively, and these two types of nodes are alternately connected to form pts topology framework. (b, c) Space-filling views for 1 showing the channels along [010] and [001] directions, respectively. (d) Ball-and-stick representation of 1 with the indium tetrahedral node shown in green and the square planar EBDC node shown in red. (e) Natural tiling representation of 1. Color code: In, green; C, gray; O, red.

The inorganic ([In(O2C)4]-) node and organic (EBDC4-) node are rationalized as having tetrahedral and square-planar geometry, respectively, and these two types of nodes are alternately connected to form pts topology framework. (b, c) Space-filling views for 1 showing the channels along [010] and [001] directions, respectively. elements.content: Similarly, reaction of In­(NO3)3·​5H2O and H4EBDC, but only using DMF as solvent, permitted the construction of the unprecedented, novel MOF, formulated by elemental analysis and SCXRD analysis as [(CH3)2­NH2]­[In­(EBDC)]·​DMF (compound 2). The 3-periodic anionic MOF consists of two crystallographically independent In3+ atoms and two EBDC4– units. Each In3+ atom is coordinated by four bidentate chelating carboxylate groups from four EBDC4– ligands to form a tetrahedral node. Each ligand binds to four separate In3+ centers to form a square-planar node. The assembly of these two types of nodes generates a distinctive 3D framework (a and Table S1), which is the first report so far to the best of our knowledge. Compound 2 contains two types of channels, i.e., rectangular and triangular in shape and measure approximately 6.366 × 4.420 Å and 5.174 × 5.174 Å, respectively (point-to-point and including van der Waals radii, b,c). The simplified two 4-connected nodes alternately connected to form a new topology (d) and with a unique tile shown in e.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 2 

Similarly, reaction of In(NO3)3⋅5H2O and H4EBDC, but only using DMF as solvent, permitted the construction of the unprecedented, novel MOF, formulated by elemental analysis and SCXRD analysis as [(CH3)2NH2][In(EBDC)]⋅DMF (compound 2). The 3-periodic anionic MOF consists of two crystallographically independent In3+ atoms and two EBDC4- units. Each In3+ atom is coordinated by four bidentate chelating carboxylate groups from four EBDC4- ligands to form a tetrahedral node. Each ligand binds to four separate In3+ centers to form a square-planar node. The assembly of these two types of nodes generates a distinctive 3D framework (a and Table S1), which is the first report so far to the best of our knowledge. Compound 2 contains two types of channels, i.e., rectangular and triangular in shape and measure approximately 6.366 × 4.420 Å and 5.174 × 5.174 Å, respectively (point-to-point and including van der Waals radii, b,c). The simplified two 4-connected nodes alternately connected to form a new topology (d) and with a unique tile shown in e.

elements.content: A description of the structure of 2: (a) The inorganic ([In­(O2C)4]−) node and organic (EBDC4–) node are rationalized as having tetrahedral and square-planar geometry, respectively, and the two types of nodes alternately connected to form a new type of topology framework. (b, c) Space-filling representations of the framework of compound 2 showing the channels along [001] and [110] directions, respectively. (d) Ball-and-stick representation of 2 with the indium tetrahedral node shown in green and the square-planar EBDC node shown in red. (e) Natural tiling representation of 2. Color code: In, green; C, gray; O, red.
elements.clean_text: 2  A description of the structure of 2: (a) The inorganic ([In(O2C)4]-) node and organic (EBDC4-) node are rationalized as having tetrahedral and square-planar geometry, respectively, and the two types of nodes alternately connected to form a new type of topology framework. (b, c) Space-filling representations of the framework of compound 2 showing the channels along [001] and [110] directions, respectively. (d) Ball-and-stick representation of 2 with the indium tetrahedral node shown in green and the square-planar EBDC node shown in red. (e) Natural tiling representation of 2. Color code: In, green; C, gray; O, red.

elements.content: Similar reaction conditions as for 2 in the presence of 1 mL of CH3CN and 0.2 mL of HNO3 in DMA (2.7 M) give polyhedral crystals formulated as [In3O­(EBDC)1.5­(H2O)3]­[NO3]·​2DMF·​2­(CH3CN)·​0.75­(H2O) (compound 3). The crystallographic analysis of 3 revealed that it crystallizes in the cubic space group Pm3̅n and its structure contains indium trimer building blocks, [In3O­(O2C)6­(H2O)3]+, whereby each indium cation adopts an octahedral [InO5­(H2O)] coordination environment. Each trimer unit is linked by six separate organic linkers to produce a novel 3D structure. The indium trimeric building units can be rationalized as a 6-connected trigonal prismatic building unit and can be regarded as a pseudo-octahedron. The organic H4EBDC linker can be simplified as a connected rectangular-planar node. Accordingly, the assembly of such 4- and 6-connected nodes results in the formation of an edge-transitive 3-periodic network with soc topology (a). To date, only few examples of trimeric building unit based MOFs with soc topology have been reported. The overall framework of compound 3 is cationic, and the charge balance is provided by disordered [NO3]− anions. Compound 3 exhibits an interesting pore system because it contains two well-defined types of infinite channels, namely, an intersecting hydrophobic and hydrophilic channel system. The relative span of the cage is estimated to be 14.96 Å, while the channels measure approximately 7.66 Å (point-to-point and including van der Waals radii, b). The simplified 4- and 6-connected nodes alternately connected to form a (4,6)-connected network (c), with two distinct tiles: [44.62] and [46.89] (d).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 3 

Similar reaction conditions as for 2 in the presence of 1 mL of CH3CN and 0.2 mL of HNO3 in DMA (2.7 M) give polyhedral crystals formulated as [In3O(EBDC)1.5(H2O)3][NO3]⋅2DMF⋅2(CH3CN)⋅0.75(H2O) (compound 3). The crystallographic analysis of 3 revealed that it crystallizes in the cubic space group Pm3̅n and its structure contains indium trimer building blocks, [In3O(O2C)6(H2O)3]+, whereby each indium cation adopts an octahedral [InO5(H2O)] coordination environment. Each trimer unit is linked by six separate organic linkers to produce a novel 3D structure. The indium trimeric building units can be rationalized as a 6-connected trigonal prismatic building unit and can be regarded as a pseudo-octahedron. The organic H4EBDC linker can be simplified as a connected rectangular-planar node. Accordingly, the assembly of such 4- and 6-connected nodes results in the formation of an edge-transitive 3-periodic network with soc topology (a). To date, only few examples of trimeric building unit based MOFs with soc topology have been reported. The overall framework of compound 3 is cationic, and the charge balance is provided by disordered [NO3]- anions. Compound 3 exhibits an interesting pore system because it contains two well-defined types of infinite channels, namely, an intersecting hydrophobic and hydrophilic channel system. The relative span of the cage is estimated to be 14.96 Å, while the channels measure approximately 7.66 Å (point-to-point and including van der Waals radii, b). The simplified 4- and 6-connected nodes alternately connected to form a (4,6)-connected network (c), with two distinct tiles: [44.62] and [46.89] (d).

elements.content: A description of the structure of 3: (a) The inorganic indium trimer node [In3O­(O2C)6­(H2O)3]+ and organic (EBDC4–) node are rationalized as having pseudo-octahedron and square-planar geometry, respectively, and the two nodes alternately connected to result in the formation of an edge-transitive 3-periodic network with soc topology. (b) Space-filling representations of the framework of compound 3 showing the channels along the [100] direction. (c) Schematic and ball-and-stick representations of 3 with soc topology. (d) Natural tiling representation of soc net.
elements.clean_text: 3  A description of the structure of 3: (a) The inorganic indium trimer node [In3O(O2C)6(H2O)3]+ and organic (EBDC4-) node are rationalized as having pseudo-octahedron and square-planar geometry, respectively, and the two nodes alternately connected to result in the formation of an edge-transitive 3-periodic network with soc topology. (b) Space-filling representations of the framework of compound 3 showing the channels along the [100] direction. (c) Schematic and ball-and-stick representations of 3 with soc topology. (d) Natural tiling representation of soc net.

elements.content: Under similar reaction conditions for 3, just changing the DMF solvent to DMA, led to the formation of a novel MOF with the formula [(CH3)2NH2]­[In3O­(EBDC)1.5­(H2O)3]2­[In­(EBDC)]3·​8DMF·​13­(CH3CN)·​10­(H2O) (compound 4). Compound 4 crystallizes in the chiral space group R32, and contains two distinctly different In3+ configurations: the monomeric [In­(O2C)4]− site and the trimeric [In3O­(O2C)6­(H2O)3]+ clusters. Each H4EBDC ligand is linked by two monomeric In3+ centers and two trimeric building units in a cis configuration to generate a novel 3D anionic network (a). Compound 4 contains three types of channels, the space-filling representations of the framework showing the channels along [100], [110], and [111] directions, respectively (b–d). If the monomeric [In­(O2C)4]− building unit is simplified as the 4-connected tetrahedral node, the trimer as the 6-connected node, and the H4EBDC ligand served as the 4-connected square node, the 3D framework of 4 can be simplified as a rare, ternary (4,4,6)-connected net (e) with four distinct tiles: [63], [64], [66], and [46.68] (f). To the best of our knowledge, only one example of an In-MOF that contains both indium monomer and trimer units has been reported.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 4 

Under similar reaction conditions for 3, just changing the DMF solvent to DMA, led to the formation of a novel MOF with the formula [(CH3)2NH2][In3O(EBDC)1.5(H2O)3]2[In(EBDC)]3⋅8DMF⋅13(CH3CN)⋅10(H2O) (compound 4). Compound 4 crystallizes in the chiral space group R32, and contains two distinctly different In3+ configurations: the monomeric [In(O2C)4]- site and the trimeric [In3O(O2C)6(H2O)3]+ clusters. Each H4EBDC ligand is linked by two monomeric In3+ centers and two trimeric building units in a cis configuration to generate a novel 3D anionic network (a). Compound 4 contains three types of channels, the space-filling representations of the framework showing the channels along [100], [110], and [111] directions, respectively (b-d). If the monomeric [In(O2C)4]- building unit is simplified as the 4-connected tetrahedral node, the trimer as the 6-connected node, and the H4EBDC ligand served as the 4-connected square node, the 3D framework of 4 can be simplified as a rare, ternary (4,4,6)-connected net (e) with four distinct tiles: [63], [64], [66], and [46.68] (f). To the best of our knowledge, only one example of an In-MOF that contains both indium monomer and trimer units has been reported.

elements.content: A description of the structure of 4: (a) The inorganic monomeric [In­(O2C)4]− node and the trimeric [In3O­(O2C)6­(H2O)3]+ node can be rationalized as tetrahedral and pseudo-octahedron geometry, respectively, and the organic (EBDC4–) is still rationalized as square-planar geometry. Each EBDC ligand is linked by two monomeric In3+ nodes and two trimeric nodes in a cis configuration to generate a novel topological network. (b–d) Space-filling representations of the framework of compound 4 showing the channels along [100], [110], and [111] directions, respectively. (e) Ball-and-stick representation of 4 with the indium tetrahedral nodes shown in green, indium trigonal prism nodes shown in green, and the square planar EBDC4– nodes shown in red. (f) Natural tiling representation of 4.

Each EBDC ligand is linked by two monomeric In3+ nodes and two trimeric nodes in a cis configuration to generate a novel topological network. (b-d) Space-filling representations of the framework of compound 4 showing the channels along [100], [110], and [111] directions, respectively. (e) Ball-and-stick representation of 4 with the indium tetrahedral nodes shown in green, indium trigonal prism nodes shown in green, and the square planar EBDC4- nodes shown in red. (f) Natural tiling representation of 4.

elements.content: If we kept the monomer [In­(O2C)4]− and trimer [In3O­(O2C)6­(H2O)3]+ as still 4- or 6-connected nodes, while the tetracarboxylate ligand is simplified as two 3-c branch points, which is according to the latest topological analysis method, the topologies of compounds 1–4 would be totally different (see Figures S5–S8). The 3D frameworks of 1–2 can be simplified as a (3,4)-connected net with Schläfli symbols of {62·84}­{62·8}2 and {6·82}2­{6·85}­{62·84}­{62·8}2, respectively, while compound 3 can be simplified as a (3,6)-connected net with Schläfli symbols of {53}3­{56·86·93}, and compound 4 is a (3,4,6)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of {6·72}12­{63·712}2­{75·8}3. The calculated result by TOPOS for the linker simplified as 3- or 4-connected node has been illustrated in Table S2.
elements.clean_text: If we kept the monomer [In(O2C)4]- and trimer [In3O(O2C)6(H2O)3]+ as still 4- or 6-connected nodes, while the tetracarboxylate ligand is simplified as two 3-c branch points, which is according to the latest topological analysis method, the topologies of compounds 1-4 would be totally different (see Figures S5-S8). The 3D frameworks of 1-2 can be simplified as a (3,4)-connected net with Schläfli symbols of {62⋅84}{62⋅8}2 and {6⋅82}2{6⋅85}{62⋅84}{62⋅8}2, respectively, while compound 3 can be simplified as a (3,6)-connected net with Schläfli symbols of {53}3{56⋅86⋅93}, and compound 4 is a (3,4,6)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of {6⋅72}12{63⋅712}2{75⋅8}3. The calculated result by TOPOS for the linker simplified as 3- or 4-connected node has been illustrated in Table S2.

elements.content: The thermal stability of compounds 1–4 has been evaluated in the temperature range of 35–700 °C under an air atmosphere (Supporting Information, Figure S3). Thermogravimetric analysis for compound 1 shows a weight loss of 43.84% (calcd: 44.08%) between 35 and 300 °C, which corresponds to the loss of C3H7ON, H2O, C2H6SO, and (CH3)2­NH2 guest in the cavity. The further weight loss of 39.50% between 300 and 500 °C should be attributed to the release of organic H4EBDC ligands (calcd: 39.23%). XRD studies indicated that the final product, upon calcinations above 500 °C, is a main phase of In2O3 (JCPDS: 65-3170).
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermal stability of compounds 1-4 has been evaluated in the temperature range of 35-700 °C under an air atmosphere (Supporting Information, Figure S3). Thermogravimetric analysis for compound 1 shows a weight loss of 43.84% (calcd: 44.08%) between 35 and 300 °C, which corresponds to the loss of C3H7ON, H2O, C2H6SO, and (CH3)2NH2 guest in the cavity. The further weight loss of 39.50% between 300 and 500 °C should be attributed to the release of organic H4EBDC ligands (calcd: 39.23%). XRD studies indicated that the final product, upon calcinations above 500 °C, is a main phase of In2O3 (JCPDS: 65-3170).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis for compound 2 shows a weight loss of 20.55% (calcd: 20.40%) between 35 and 160 °C, which corresponds to the loss of C3H7ON and (CH3)2­NH2 guest in the cavity. On further heating, a two-step weight loss of 55.57% between 160 and 500 °C should be attributed to the release of organic H4EBDC ligands (calcd: 55.84%). XRD studies indicated that the final product, upon calcinations above 500 °C, is a main phase of In2O3 (JCPDS: 65-3170).
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis for compound 2 shows a weight loss of 20.55% (calcd: 20.40%) between 35 and 160 °C, which corresponds to the loss of C3H7ON and (CH3)2NH2 guest in the cavity. On further heating, a two-step weight loss of 55.57% between 160 and 500 °C should be attributed to the release of organic H4EBDC ligands (calcd: 55.84%). XRD studies indicated that the final product, upon calcinations above 500 °C, is a main phase of In2O3 (JCPDS: 65-3170).

elements.content: For compound 3, thermogravimetric analysis shows a weight loss of 32.98% (calcd: 32.73%) between 35 and 380 °C, which corresponds to the loss of C3H7ON, CH3CN, H2O, and NO3 – guest in the cavity. The further weight loss of 35.42% between 380 and 500 °C should be attributed to the release of organic H4EBDC ligands (calcd: 35.64%). The different temperature XRD studies show that the framework of compound 3 was stable to 300 °C. XRD studies indicated that the final product, upon calcinations above 500 °C, is a main phase of In2O3 (JCPDS: 65-3170).

Gas Adsorption Properties

The total solvent-accessible volumes for 1, 2, 3, and 4 were estimated to be ~73.1, ~72.5, ~64.7, and ~67.1%, respectively, by summing voxels more than 1.2 Å away from the framework using PLATON software. Though compounds 1 and 2 have large solvent-accessible volumes in theory, neither of them has any noticeable adsorption for N2 at low temperature, which should be due to the plausible framework collapse after removing the solvents in the pores. In contrast to compounds 1 and 2, it is worth noting that both compounds 3 and 4 could maintain their crystallinity upon heating temperature up to 300 °C after full removal of solvent guest molecules (Figure S2). The argon adsorption/desorption studies of 3 and 4 revealed that both have reversible type I isotherms (), indicative of permanent microporosity. The Langmuir and BET surface areas for 3 were estimated to be 1548 and 1285 m2/g. The calculated pore volume was estimated to be 0.53 cm3/g. The Langmuir and BET surface areas, and free pore volume for 4, were estimated at 1355 and 1129 m2/g and 0.49 cm3 g-1. The surface area of 4 is higher than that of most of known anionic In-MOFs (190-1441 m2/g).

elements.content: Because of the charge reversal framework features of 3 and 4 (3 adopts an overall cationic framework, whereas 4 has an anionic framework), it is interesting to evaluate the impact of the pore size, shape, and the charge on the uptake and sorption energetics of H2 and CO2 adsorbates. 3 and 4 exhibit significant uptake capacity for CO2 and H2. The CO2 uptake at 273 K and 1 atm for 3 and 4 are 91.0 and 82.5 cm3/g, respectively (). Although abundant MOF structures have been reported, MOFs with CO2 uptake > 90 cm3/g at 273 K and 1 atm are still scarce. In the case of H2, 3 and 4 revealed a storage capacity of 1.84 and 1.45 wt % at 77 K and 1 atm, respectively (). The Q st for CO2 was found to be higher in the entire studied range for 4 with a more pronounced difference at low loading, 35.2 kJ mol–1 vs 29.7 kJ mol–1 for 3 (a).

elements.content: Since the CO2 isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) represents the strength of the interactions between CO2 molecules and the framework lattice, there are two different inorganic MBBs in compound 4, which would provide more open metal sites; besides that, some Lewis basic amines also occupied in the pores. Compound 4 has smaller pores, but the pores are large enough for adsorption CO2. All of these might result in stronger interactions between the framework and adsorbed CO2, and then resulted in higher Q st for compound 4 compared to 3.

elements.content: For H2, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) on 4 was also found to be higher than that on 3 (7.2 vs 6.7 kJ mol–1 at low loading) (b). These observed improvements on the H2 and CO2 sorption energetics in the case of 4 are likely attributed to the narrow pore size and localized charge effect. CO2, N2, and CH4 adsorption isotherms for compounds 3 and 4 have been also measured. As shown in , both compounds 3 (a) and 4 (b) exhibit a higher affinity and capacity for CO2 than for other gases. The CO2 uptake at 8000 mbar and 298 K for compounds 3 and 4 is 6.92 and 8.41 mmol g–1, respectively, and very little N2 uptake capacity (1.25 and 1.02 mmol g–1, respectively). On the basis of CO2, CH4, and N2 adsorption isotherms measured at 298 K, the initial slopes of adsorption isotherms were estimated and then used to estimate the CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 selectivities (as ratios of the initial slopes) (). As a result, the CO2/N2 selectivities of compounds 3 and 4 are 17:1 and 21:1, respectively. The CO2/CH4 selectivities are 4:1 and 6:1, respectively. It is to note that, the CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4 selectivities are comparable to those of ZIF-68 and a porous carbon monolith.

elements.content: In summary, four indium–organic frameworks have been successfully synthesized by simply changing the solvent under similar synthetic conditions. These materials exhibit rich structural chemistry and topologies. Both compounds 3 and 4 exhibit significant uptake capacity for CO2 and H2, and compound 4 displays improved sorption energetics due to its narrow pore size and charge effect compared to 3. The ability to generate different building units (indium monomer, trimer, combination of monomer and trimer) in situ, by controlling the solvent system, presents a prospective route for the design of novel porous MOF materials with different topologies and charged frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, four indium-organic frameworks have been successfully synthesized by simply changing the solvent under similar synthetic conditions. These materials exhibit rich structural chemistry and topologies. Both compounds 3 and 4 exhibit significant uptake capacity for CO2 and H2, and compound 4 displays improved sorption energetics due to its narrow pore size and charge effect compared to 3. The ability to generate different building units (indium monomer, trimer, combination of monomer and trimer) in situ, by controlling the solvent system, presents a prospective route for the design of novel porous MOF materials with different topologies and charged frameworks.

cln_elements.content:
Similar reaction conditions as for 2 in the presence of 1 mL of CH3CN and 0.2 mL of HNO3 in DMA (2.7 M) give polyhedral crystals formulated as [In3O­(EBDC)1.5­(H2O)3]­[NO3]·​2DMF·​2­(CH3CN)·​0.75­(H2O) (compound 3). The crystallographic analysis of 3 revealed that it crystallizes in the cubic space group Pm3̅n and its structure contains indium trimer building blocks, [In3O­(O2C)6­(H2O)3]+, whereby each indium cation adopts an octahedral [InO5­(H2O)] coordination environment. Each trimer unit is linked by six separate organic linkers to produce a novel 3D structure. The indium trimeric building units can be rationalized as a 6-connected trigonal prismatic building unit and can be regarded as a pseudo-octahedron. The organic H4EBDC linker can be simplified as a connected rectangular-planar node. Accordingly, the assembly of such 4- and 6-connected nodes results in the formation of an edge-transitive 3-periodic network with soc topology (a). To date, only few examples of trimeric building unit based MOFs with soc topology have been reported. The overall framework of compound 3 is cationic, and the charge balance is provided by disordered [NO3]− anions. Compound 3 exhibits an interesting pore system because it contains two well-defined types of infinite channels, namely, an intersecting hydrophobic and hydrophilic channel system. The relative span of the cage is estimated to be 14.96 Å, while the channels measure approximately 7.66 Å (point-to-point and including van der Waals radii, b). The simplified 4- and 6-connected nodes alternately connected to form a (4,6)-connected network (c), with two distinct tiles: [44.62] and [46.89] (d).

Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermal stability of compounds 1–4 has been evaluated in the temperature range of 35–700 °C under an air atmosphere (Supporting Information, Figure S3). Thermogravimetric analysis for compound 1 shows a weight loss of 43.84% (calcd: 44.08%) between 35 and 300 °C, which corresponds to the loss of C3H7ON, H2O, C2H6SO, and (CH3)2­NH2 guest in the cavity. The further weight loss of 39.50% between 300 and 500 °C should be attributed to the release of organic H4EBDC ligands (calcd: 39.23%). XRD studies indicated that the final product, upon calcinations above 500 °C, is a main phase of In2O3 (JCPDS: 65-3170).

Thermogravimetric analysis for compound 2 shows a weight loss of 20.55% (calcd: 20.40%) between 35 and 160 °C, which corresponds to the loss of C3H7ON and (CH3)2­NH2 guest in the cavity. On further heating, a two-step weight loss of 55.57% between 160 and 500 °C should be attributed to the release of organic H4EBDC ligands (calcd: 55.84%). XRD studies indicated that the final product, upon calcinations above 500 °C, is a main phase of In2O3 (JCPDS: 65-3170).

For compound 3, thermogravimetric analysis shows a weight loss of 32.98% (calcd: 32.73%) between 35 and 380 °C, which corresponds to the loss of C3H7ON, CH3CN, H2O, and NO3 – guest in the cavity. The further weight loss of 35.42% between 380 and 500 °C should be attributed to the release of organic H4EBDC ligands (calcd: 35.64%). The different temperature XRD studies show that the framework of compound 3 was stable to 300 °C. XRD studies indicated that the final product, upon calcinations above 500 °C, is a main phase of In2O3 (JCPDS: 65-3170).

Thermogravimetric analysis for compound 4 shows a weight loss of 33.20% (calcd: 33.07%) between 35 and 350 °C, which corresponds to the loss of C4H9ON, CH3CN, H2O, and (CH3)2­NH2 guest in the cavity. The further weight loss of 41.35% between 350 and 520 °C should be attributed to the release of organic H4EBDC ligands (calcd: 40.52%). XRD studies indicated that the final product, upon calcinations above 500 °C, is a main phase of In2O3 (JCPDS: 65-3170).

Gas Adsorption Properties

The total solvent-accessible volumes for 1, 2, 3, and 4 were estimated to be ∼73.1, ∼72.5, ∼64.7, and ∼67.1%, respectively, by summing voxels more than 1.2 Å away from the framework using PLATON software. Though compounds 1 and 2 have large solvent-accessible volumes in theory, neither of them has any noticeable adsorption for N2 at low temperature, which should be due to the plausible framework collapse after removing the solvents in the pores. In contrast to compounds 1 and 2, it is worth noting that both compounds 3 and 4 could maintain their crystallinity upon heating temperature up to 300 °C after full removal of solvent guest molecules (Figure S2). The argon adsorption/desorption studies of 3 and 4 revealed that both have reversible type I isotherms (), indicative of permanent microporosity. The Langmuir and BET surface areas for 3 were estimated to be 1548 and 1285 m2/g. The calculated pore volume was estimated to be 0.53 cm3/g. The Langmuir and BET surface areas, and free pore volume for 4, were estimated at 1355 and 1129 m2/g and 0.49 cm3 g–1. The surface area of 4 is higher than that of most of known anionic In-MOFs (190–1441 m2/g).

Because of the charge reversal framework features of 3 and 4 (3 adopts an overall cationic framework, whereas 4 has an anionic framework), it is interesting to evaluate the impact of the pore size, shape, and the charge on the uptake and sorption energetics of H2 and CO2 adsorbates. 3 and 4 exhibit significant uptake capacity for CO2 and H2. The CO2 uptake at 273 K and 1 atm for 3 and 4 are 91.0 and 82.5 cm3/g, respectively (). Although abundant MOF structures have been reported, MOFs with CO2 uptake > 90 cm3/g at 273 K and 1 atm are still scarce. In the case of H2, 3 and 4 revealed a storage capacity of 1.84 and 1.45 wt % at 77 K and 1 atm, respectively (). The Q st for CO2 was found to be higher in the entire studied range for 4 with a more pronounced difference at low loading, 35.2 kJ mol–1 vs 29.7 kJ mol–1 for 3 (a).

The argon adsorption/desorption studies of 3 and 4 revealed that both have reversible type I isotherms (), indicative of permanent microporosity. The Langmuir and BET surface areas for 3 were estimated to be 1548 and 1285 m2/g. The calculated pore volume was estimated to be 0.53 cm3/g. The Langmuir and BET surface areas, and free pore volume for 4, were estimated at 1355 and 1129 m2/g and 0.49 cm3 g-1. The surface area of 4 is higher than that of most of known anionic In-MOFs (190-1441 m2/g). 

Because of the charge reversal framework features of 3 and 4 (3 adopts an overall cationic framework, whereas 4 has an anionic framework), it is interesting to evaluate the impact of the pore size, shape, and the charge on the uptake and sorption energetics of H2 and CO2 adsorbates. 3 and 4 exhibit significant uptake capacity for CO2 and H2. The CO2 uptake at 273 K and 1 atm for 3 and 4 are 91.0 and 82.5 cm3/g, respectively (). Although abundant MOF structures have been reported, MOFs with CO2 uptake > 90 cm3/g at 273 K and 1 atm are still scarce. In the case of H2, 3 and 4 revealed a storage capacity of 1.84 and 1.45 wt % at 77 K and 1 atm, respectively (). The Q st for CO2 was found to be higher in the entire studied range for 4 with a more pronounced difference at low loading, 35.2 kJ mol-1 vs 29.7 kJ mol-1 for 3 (a).

cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Four Indium-Organic Frameworks Have Been Synthesized by Changing the Solvent under Similar Synthetic Conditions

cln_elements.content: A description of the structure of 1: (a) Each In3+ center is eight-coordinated to oxygen atoms of four carboxylate groups from four EBDC4– ligands, and each ligand binds to four separate In3+ centers. The inorganic ([In­(O2C)4]−) node and organic (EBDC4–) node are rationalized as having tetrahedral and square-planar geometry, respectively, and these two types of nodes are alternately connected to form pts topology framework. (b, c) Space-filling views for 1 showing the channels along [010] and [001] directions, respectively. (d) Ball-and-stick representation of 1 with the indium tetrahedral node shown in green and the square planar EBDC node shown in red. (e) Natural tiling representation of 1. Color code: In, green; C, gray; O, red.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  A description of the structure of 1: (a) Each In3+ center is eight-coordinated to oxygen atoms of four carboxylate groups from four EBDC4- ligands, and each ligand binds to four separate In3+ centers. The inorganic ([In(O2C)4]-) node and organic (EBDC4-) node are rationalized as having tetrahedral and square-planar geometry, respectively, and these two types of nodes are alternately connected to form pts topology framework. (b, c) Space-filling views for 1 showing the channels along [010] and [001] directions, respectively. (d) Ball-and-stick representation of 1 with the indium tetrahedral node shown in green and the square planar EBDC node shown in red. (e) Natural tiling representation of 1. Color code: In, green; C, gray; O, red.

cln_elements.content: A description of the structure of 2: (a) The inorganic ([In­(O2C)4]−) node and organic (EBDC4–) node are rationalized as having tetrahedral and square-planar geometry, respectively, and the two types of nodes alternately connected to form a new type of topology framework. (b, c) Space-filling representations of the framework of compound 2 showing the channels along [001] and [110] directions, respectively. (d) Ball-and-stick representation of 2 with the indium tetrahedral node shown in green and the square-planar EBDC node shown in red. (e) Natural tiling representation of 2. Color code: In, green; C, gray; O, red.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  A description of the structure of 2: (a) The inorganic ([In(O2C)4]-) node and organic (EBDC4-) node are rationalized as having tetrahedral and square-planar geometry, respectively, and the two types of nodes alternately connected to form a new type of topology framework. (b, c) Space-filling representations of the framework of compound 2 showing the channels along [001] and [110] directions, respectively. (d) Ball-and-stick representation of 2 with the indium tetrahedral node shown in green and the square-planar EBDC node shown in red. (e) Natural tiling representation of 2. Color code: In, green; C, gray; O, red.

cln_elements.content: A description of the structure of 3: (a) The inorganic indium trimer node [In3O­(O2C)6­(H2O)3]+ and organic (EBDC4–) node are rationalized as having pseudo-octahedron and square-planar geometry, respectively, and the two nodes alternately connected to result in the formation of an edge-transitive 3-periodic network with soc topology. (b) Space-filling representations of the framework of compound 3 showing the channels along the [100] direction. (c) Schematic and ball-and-stick representations of 3 with soc topology. (d) Natural tiling representation of soc net.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  A description of the structure of 3: (a) The inorganic indium trimer node [In3O(O2C)6(H2O)3]+ and organic (EBDC4-) node are rationalized as having pseudo-octahedron and square-planar geometry, respectively, and the two nodes alternately connected to result in the formation of an edge-transitive 3-periodic network with soc topology. (b) Space-filling representations of the framework of compound 3 showing the channels along the [100] direction. (c) Schematic and ball-and-stick representations of 3 with soc topology. (d) Natural tiling representation of soc net.

cln_elements.content: A description of the structure of 4: (a) The inorganic monomeric [In­(O2C)4]− node and the trimeric [In3O­(O2C)6­(H2O)3]+ node can be rationalized as tetrahedral and pseudo-octahedron geometry, respectively, and the organic (EBDC4–) is still rationalized as square-planar geometry. Each EBDC ligand is linked by two monomeric In3+ nodes and two trimeric nodes in a cis configuration to generate a novel topological network. (b–d) Space-filling representations of the framework of compound 4 showing the channels along [100], [110], and [111] directions, respectively. (e) Ball-and-stick representation of 4 with the indium tetrahedral nodes shown in green, indium trigonal prism nodes shown in green, and the square planar EBDC4– nodes shown in red. (f) Natural tiling representation of 4.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  A description of the structure of 4: (a) The inorganic monomeric [In(O2C)4]- node and the trimeric [In3O(O2C)6(H2O)3]+ node can be rationalized as tetrahedral and pseudo-octahedron geometry, respectively, and the organic (EBDC4-) is still rationalized as square-planar geometry. Each EBDC ligand is linked by two monomeric In3+ nodes and two trimeric nodes in a cis configuration to generate a novel topological network. (b-d) Space-filling representations of the framework of compound 4 showing the channels along [100], [110], and [111] directions, respectively. (e) Ball-and-stick representation of 4 with the indium tetrahedral nodes shown in green, indium trigonal prism nodes shown in green, and the square planar EBDC4- nodes shown in red. (f) Natural tiling representation of 4.
